conclusion: Analyze the problem step-by-step.
Determine the uniform velocity v1 when no voltage is applied.
When no voltage is applied, both oil droplets A and B fall uniformly under the influence of gravity and air resistance.
The forces acting on each droplet are gravity (mg) and air resistance (f = k m^(1/3) v).
At uniform velocity v1, the net force is zero, so mg - k m^(1/3) v1 = 0.
Given that both droplets fall through a distance h1 in time t.
h1 = v1 t, so v1 = h1 / t.
Equating the two expressions for v1 gives k = gm_0^(2/3) t / h1.
Determine the uniform velocity v2 of droplet B when voltage is applied.
When the voltage U is applied, droplet B starts moving upwards uniformly.
The forces acting on droplet B are gravity (mg), electric force (qE where E = U/d), and air resistance (f = k m^(1/3) v).
At uniform velocity v2 upwards, the net force is zero, so qU/d - mg - k m^(1/3) v2 = 0.
Given that droplet B rises through a distance h2 in time t.
h2 = v2 t, so v2 = h2 / t.
Equating the two expressions for v2 gives k m_0^(1/3) h2/t = qU/d - mg.
Determine the proportionality constant k.
From the equation, k = (qU/d - mg) / (m_0^(1/3) h2/t).
Substitute k from Step 1 into the equation from Step 2: gm_0^(2/3) t/h1 m_0^(1/3) h2/t = qU/d - mg.
g m_0 h2/h1 = qU/d - mg.
